subject: Re: [junit] Problem with configuration classes

messageBody:
Why not create Listeners with one or more Handlers and have the
Listeners pass the Event to all of their Handlers. The Handlers decide
whether or not they care about the event; if so, do something about it.
That way you can mock the Handler implementation, create a Listener with
it and test that the Listener is doing the right thing. Then you test
the specific implementations of the Handler, which is where the most
interesting test is anyway -- 'Does the Handler affect the System
properly?'.

=jason

On Sat, 2003-09-06 at 07:05, trz wrote:
<snip>
> I'm trying to understand how to handle some "configuration" problems.
>
> This is the current example, but I found this same problem other times.
>
> I have a class that receive events. Depending on the event type the
> event is dispatched (using a map lookup) to the registered handler.
> Nothing more.
>
> To test this I started populating the event->handler map in the
> EventListener constructor (looking for the simplest possibile...).
> This made the tests hard: I cannot test just the EventListener class
> because it was already filled with app specific handlers and was not
> possible to add other handlers.
> So I moved the configuration of the EventListener outside.
> Now I have
> - EventListener: just receive the events, lookup handler and activate
> handler
> - EventListenerFactory: create an EventListener configuring it for this app
> - a lot of single EventHandler
>
> Now I can test EventListener and each EventHandler without problems, but
> I cannot find any useful test for EventListenerFactory.
</snip>
